revision.text:
{{TopNav|prev=Data Types|next=Alter Table}} {{BookCat}}
__TOC__

Hi,
My name is Elise and I am 22 years old. I currently live in Stirling, Scotland, but I am originally from Oslo, Norway. I have a bachelor's degree in Journalism, but next year I will start my bachelor's degree in Psychology.
My home project is English Wikipedia and there is more about me [[wikipedia:User:MartinPoulter|on my user profile there]].

= '''Introduction''' =
''"Growth hacker (noun)-one who's '''passion''' and '''focus''' is <u>growth</u> through use of a '''testable''' and '''scalable''' methodology. A growth hackers works within the parameters of a scaleable and repeatable method for growth, <u>driven by product</u> and <u>inspired by data</u>. A growth hacker lives at the intersection of data, product, and marketing. <ref name = "quote">[http://www.slideshare.net/ryanholiday/19-growth-hacker-quotes Link text] </ref>" -Aaron Ginn, Head of Growth, STUMBLEUPON ''
==''What is Growth Hacking?''==
Growth hacking is a method of rapidly and inexpensively growing a company’s user base, sales, or market share. <ref>http://blog.ourcrowd.com/index.php/2014/01/21/what-is-a-growth-hacker-and-why-every-startup-needs-one/</ref> Coined by Sean Ellis in 2010, this low-cost strategy often employs technological solutions such as search engine optimization, website analytics,[http://www.creativeguerrillamarketing.com/what-is-guerrilla-marketing/ guerrilla marketing], optimizing user experience and user interface, and leveraging social media platforms to enhance user experience <ref name= "quicksprout"> [http://www.quicksprout.com/the-definitive-guide-to-growth-hacking-chapter-1/] </ref>. Since being coined in 2010, the term and its associated marketing strategies have become popular in the tech industry and have begun to branch out into other sectors, leading to the first [http://growthhackersconference.com/ Growth Hackers Conference] in 2013.
==''Profile of a Growth Hacker''==
''“Many of the growth hacking descriptions on the web are unnecessarily restrictive. I don’t believe growth hackers must be formal engineers when many of the most well-regarded growth hackers don’t code regularly.<ref name = quicksprout">[http://www.quicksprout.com/the-definitive-guide-to-growth-hacking-chapter-2/] </ref>” -Gagan Biyani, Co-Founder of Udemy, Growth Hacker ''
A typical growth hacker is tech-savvy, highly analytical, and data-driven <ref name="whenGHgoesbad"> [http://techcrunch.com/2014/01/03/when-growth-hacking-goes-bad//] </ref>. Although many growth hackers are programmers, growth hackers can come from a variety of backgrounds. Though many growth hacking strategies are technical in nature, they often also require outside-of-the-box thinking, creativity, and comfort dealing with qualitative data and ambiguity <ref name="whenGHgoesbad"> [http://techcrunch.com/2014/01/03/when-growth-hacking-goes-bad//] </ref>. According to Aaron Ginn via [http://techcrunch.com/2012/10/21/defining-a-growth-hacker-building-growth-into-your-team/ TechCrunch], a strong growth hacking team typically consists of a programmer, analyst, and a marketer who combine their skills to achieve rapid growth. The web developer manipulates and designs marketing platforms, the analyst analyzes data to expose trends and motivate strategies, and the marketer pitches growth recommendations to clients.
='''Growth Hacking and Professional Ethics'''= ==''Knowing Where to Draw the Line''==
The term [http://searchsecurity.techtarget.com/definition/hacker hacking] is often perceived negatively due to its use to describe individuals who exploit security flaws in computer systems in an illicit manner. When used in the context of growth hacking, however, hacking should hold a neutral or positive association. [http://www.growtheverywhere.com/sean-ellis/ Eric Ellis], coiner of the term "growth hacking", recommends that "people don’t get caught up on the term “growth hacker” or even a specific definition for it" <ref name="EllisQuote"> [http://blog.clarity.fm/what-300-years-of-growth-hacking-can-teach-us/] </ref> , but rather "focus instead on the concepts behind it." <ref name="EllisQuote"> [http://blog.clarity.fm/what-300-years-of-growth-hacking-can-teach-us/] </ref> According to Ellis, growth hackers simply manipulate data to find a marketing highway for growth. Though the most critical goal of growth hacking is growth, companies typically try to avoid growth hacking techniques that exploit users.<ref name="ourcrowdblog"> [http://blog.ourcrowd.com/index.php/2014/01/21/what-is-a-growth-hacker-and-why-every-startup-needs-one/] </ref> In this regard, the saying "one bad apple can spoil the whole bunch" <ref name = "bad apple"> [http://voices.yahoo.com/popular-phrases-origin-meaning-one-bad-apple-2718025.html?cat=37] </ref> applies to growth hacking techniques. Some growth hackers work to achieve growth without regard to the best interests of the company reputation and customer well-being. Some such hackers rely on spamming, questionable means of obtaining user data and information, and practices that could be considered slander of competitors. While their tactics may result in quick money, sabotaging reputations and customer trust does not benefit the company in the long run. Furthermore, the "bad apples" sour the image of growth hackers and what they can do to help companies experience incredible growth and prosperity.<ref name="ourcrowdblog"> [http://blog.ourcrowd.com/index.php/2014/01/21/what-is-a-growth-hacker-and-why-every-startup-needs-one/] </ref>
[http://www.merriam-webster.com/thesaurus/unethical Unethical]and unprofessional tactics used by some growth hackers include, but are not limited too, taking aggressive action to obtain email addresses and personal information of a target population, [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Internet_Technologies/Email_spam spamming], inappropriately slandering competitor products, false advertising,and secretly tracking customer internet habits. <ref name="whenGHgoesbad"> [http://techcrunch.com/2014/01/03/when-growth-hacking-goes-bad//] </ref> As a company looking to hire growth hackers, it is key to note that growth hackers see their growth techniques as geared towards "bringing in more traffic and putting more users at the top of the conversion funnel," not as ethical or unethical.<ref name="kissmetrics"> [http://blog.kissmetrics.com/growth-hack-content-marketing//] </ref> Growth hackers and their unique techniques need to be compatible with they work for so that the context of growth goals and objectives are clearly defined and understood. In regards to professionalism, "professionalism is about more than how you behave in practice;" it also involves the core values and attitudes held by an individual<ref name="Professionalism"> [http://www.southampton.ac.uk/medu/curriculum_design_and_delivery/professionalism.page] </ref>. The values and attitudes of individual growth hackers shape the image of the profession as a whole.
In the digital world, social messaging applications are often known as a top offender of presumably unethical and unprofessional growth hacking techniques. <ref name="whenGHgoesbad"> [http://techcrunch.com/2014/01/03/when-growth-hacking-goes-bad//] </ref> For example, spamming techniques are common on applications like [http://www.gotinder.com/ Tinder], a dating application, and [http://www.insidemobileapps.com/2013/04/04/glide-brings-instant-video-messaging-to-mobile/ Glide], a video application. These applications allow users to send non-users messages with links to download. Labeling content as spam is ultimately left up to the discretion of the receiver and if it is unsolicited and unwanted, the content is often seen as unethical. <ref name="whenGHgoesbad"> [http://techcrunch.com/2014/01/03/when-growth-hacking-goes-bad//] </ref> Fortunately, there are also successful ethical growth hacking techniques. The most important ethical technique in growth hacking is reliance on data and data analysis. Data is what drives good, honest growth hacking.<ref name="whenGHgoesbad"> [http://techcrunch.com/2014/01/03/when-growth-hacking-goes-bad//] </ref> In the cases of Tinder and Glide, data analytics could have been utilized to pinpoint trends in the target populations instead of inundating users with spam. Furthermore, data analysis can highlight the behavior of users allowing growth hackers to tailor their marketing in a fashion that pulls the users in rather than pushing them away with unsolicited downloads. Growth hacking techniques should be like an attractive side of a magnet; the techniques should be so enticing that the customer uses, clicks, downloads,or purchases on their own terms without being bombarded.
==''Normalization of Deviance''== One aspect of professional ethics that pertains to growth hacking is [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Professionalism/Diane_Vaughan_and_the_normalization_of_deviance Diane Vaughan's] theory of normalization of deviance. Growth hacking techniques are subject to gradually sway away from what the public may see as ethical. The sway may come in the form of content lacking integrity, spamming, slandering, or other unethical techniques discussed previously. These techniques are often used by growth hackers who see growth as being more important than the reputation of a company or the well-being of the consumer. Though these techniques often lead to short term growth, they fail to lead to long term success. These unethical practices of growth hacking are often identified and exposed by the public, which can lead to a decrease in company credibility, faith, and ultimately growth.
='''Case Studies'''=
==''Leveraging''== One of the most popular examples of growth hacking was [https://www.airbnb.com/ AirBNB's] leveraging of Craigslist to rapidly expand its user base. In the two years following AirBNB's 2008 launch, AirBNB's marketing team employed several growth strategies aimed at tapping into Craigslist's then much larger user base. First, AirBNB engineers reverse engineered Craigslist's posting mechanism. In doing so, AirBNB was able to offer its users an option to post a new AirBNB listing directly to Craigslist in the form of a Craigslist post that would then link back to AirBNB. This tactic both enabled early AirBNB users to advertise their listings to a much wider audience and brought many Craigslist users to the AirBNB platform. Though not an illicit tactic per se, Craigslist eventually resolved the vulnerability that enabled external sites to create listings, thus bringing an end to that functionality for AirBNB users<ref name="The Definiteive Guide to Growth Hacking"> [http://www.quicksprout.com/the-definitive-guide-to-growth-hacking-chapter-1/]</ref>.
The second tactic employed by AirBNB was to send messages recommending AirBNB to Craigslist users who posted rental listings similar to those found on AirBNB. This tactic, considered by some as [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Internet_Technologies/Email_spam spamming], was detailed most notably by web developer Dave Gooden, who works in the vacation rental industry and was curious about the source of AirBNB's rapid growth <ref name="How AirBNB Became a Billion Dollar Company" >[http://davegooden.com/2011/05/how-airbnb-became-a-billion-dollar-company/]</ref>. In his 2011 blog post "How AirBNB Became a Billion Dollar Company", Gooden revealed his investigation into AirBNB's growth tactics. After posting a rental listing on Craigslist, he received an email from a random Gmail account recommending AirBNB. He then created his own rental site and listed one of the rental properties from that site on Craigslist, only to receive a similar email recommending he list his rental on AirBNB. So many Craigslist users likely received similar messages from AirBNB after posting rental properties and wound up listing their rentals on AirBNB as well.
Though neither of these tactics were illegal, they both call the ethics of growth hacking into principle. On one hand, AirBNB took advantage of another website's existing user base and sent spam. At the same time, AirBNB turned into a respectable service that now allows people to rent places to stay in 34,000 cities in 192 countries <ref name="AirBNB">[https://www.airbnb.com/]</ref>.
==''Incentivization''== Many companies are offering incentives for users to refer friends in order to gain more exposure. [https://www.dropbox.com/help/15/en Dropbox], for one, gives a user 2 gigabytes of cloud storage space immediately when you sign up. Then once you're a user, you can send a referral link to your friends and if those friends use that referral link you and that friend both get added space onto your account; 500 megabytes per referral going up to 16 gigabytes for free users and 1 gigabyte per referral going up to 32 gigabytes for paid users. <ref>[https://www.dropbox.com/help/54/en]</ref>. Referring a friend is not the only way to receive free space, giving feedback on the site, connecting social media accounts, using Dropbox as a primary photo storage, and linking an iOS mail account will all give users more free space <ref>[https://www.dropbox.com/help/15/en]</ref>.
Venmo is a mobile application that lets users pay friends or other users directly through the application. You can link credit cards, debit cards, and bank accounts in order to withdraw and deposit money <ref>[https://venmo.com/info/product]</ref>. Their [https://help.venmo.com/customer/portal/articles/1322637-how-do-i-invite-new-users- incentive program] used to pay the user $5 for each friend they refer. Because the application is primarily used for payment purposes, an extra $5 on your account is something not many people will turn down.
Other companies who participate in bonuses for referring friends are [http://rewards.na.leagueoflegends.com/ League of Legends], [http://www.marriott.com/marriott-rewards/refer-a-friend.mi Marriot hotels], [http://www.verizonwireless.com/b2c/support/referral-rewards Verizon wireless], [https://www316.americanexpress.com/iFormsSecure/un/UK/Refer-A-Friend/iforms.do?cuid=emgmUpliftMGMER_en_GB&evtsrc=link&evttype=0&mgmerSource=mgmerHub American Express], [http://www.orbitz.com/rewards/refer-a-friend/ Orbitz], [https://www.groupon.com/visitor_referral Groupon], [http://www.directv.com/DTVAPP/referral/referralProgram.jsp DirectTV], and many others.
='''Conclusion'''= Because growth hacking is a relatively new concept and many of the key growth hacking strategies are still evolving, the ethics of growth hacking will continue to shift. In science and engineering fields, mistakes and poor decisions can potentially lead to loss of life or massive damage to property and the environment. Examples of such mistakes and poor decisions are illustrated by cases such as the [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Professionalism/Therac-25 Therac-25], [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Professionalism/Rodney_Rocha_and_Columbia Rodney Rocha and Columbia], and [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Professionalism/Apollo_13 Apollo 13]. The greatest risks, if they can even be considered risks, currently posed by growth hacking are consumer annoyance (due to spam and similar methods) and possible theft of another company's user base. As growth hacking continues to become more commonplace among tech companies and expands into other industries, we will likely alter our definition and perception of growth hacking, particularly as it pertains to professionalism and ethics.

page.title: IB Biology HL (First Exams 2009): A Complete Study Guide

revision.comment: Created first page of study guide, along with links to each topic.
revision.text:
== Preface ==
This book has been created as a study guide for IB students in the Biology Higher Level course. However, this resource may prove useful for Standard Level Biology students. The Higher Level material is clearly marked.
The book has been divided into syllabus topics and outcomes to aid revision.
== Table of Contents ==
=== Core Material ===
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 1: Statistical Analysis|Topic 1: Statistical Analysis]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 2: Cells|Topic 2: Cells]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 3: Chemical Elements and Water|Topic 3: Chemical Elements and Water]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 4: Genetics|Topic 4: Genetics]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 5: Ecology and Evolution|Topic 5: Ecology and Evolution]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 6: Human Health and Physiology|Topic 6: Human Health and Physiology]]
=== Additional Higher Level Material ===
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 7: Nucleic Acids and Proteins|Topic 7: Nucleic Acids and Proteins]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 8: Cell Respiration and Photosynthesis|Topic 8: Cell Respiration and Photosynthesis]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 9: Plant Science|Topic 9: Plant Science]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 10: Genetics|Topic 10: Genetics]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Topic 11: Human Health and Physiology|Topic 11: Human Health and Physiology]]
=== Options SL ===
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option A: Human Nutrition and Health|Option A: Human Nutrition and Health]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option B: Physiology of Exercise|Option B: Physiology of Exercise]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option C: Cells and Energy|Option C: Cells and Energy]]
=== Options SL and HL ===
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option D: Evolution|Option D: Evolution]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option E: Neurobiology and Behaviour|Option E: Neurobiology and Behaviour]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option F: Microbes and Biotechnology|Option F: Microbes and Biotechnology]]
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option G: Ecology and Conservation|Option G: Ecology and Conservation]]
=== Options HL ===
[[{{FULLBOOKNAME}}/Option H: Further Human Physiology|Option H: Further Human Physiology]]

This page has two purposes; first, to provide a location to bring together the content from each team members weekly wiki documentation in a central location to improve information sharing and access while documenting the progress of the project as a whole, and second, to provide a forum for bringing the project documentation into line with the CDIO documentation format.
The four types of project documentation come from the [http://www.cdio.org/files/project/file/cdio_syllabus_v2.pdf cdio.org's syllabus]. CDIO has a chance of evolving into a world wide engineering accreditation organization. CDIO is a world wide organization that evolved out of MIT aerospace engineering. As of fall 2012 there are 90 members worldwide including 15 US Universities. For a better introduction, read this [[b:General_Engineering_Introduction/CDIO|general engineering introduction]] wikibook page.
These are links to the four CDIO syllabus sections. These links are a maximal set of possible engineering tasks that need to be documented. All engineering project tasks have to be named in the outline. No project or CDIO document is expected to do all tasks. Copy text from the pages linked below and add information to document that your group has considered and addressed important areas of concern relative to your project.
*[[BDolge/BycycleTurnSignal/CDIO/Minimal_Conceive|Conceive]] CDIO When initially tasked with engineering a bicycle turn signal, the first step in starting the project was deciding what would need to be accomplished in order for the project to be considered a success. While a bicycle turn signal seemed very straight forward,[https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:CFernandez I] knew that it would require a clear set of parameters in order to be completed- so I initiated a brainstorming session to help conceptualize the finished project. The group agreed that the light source utilized, as well as the form factor of the turn signal would be vital. The size of the turn signal needed to be large enough to allow visibility from distances of at least ten feet, and the light source needed to be visible in the late evening hours. *[[BDolge/BycycleTurnSignal/CDIO/Minimal_Design|Design]] CDIO *[[BDolge/BycycleTurnSignal/CDIO/Minimal_Implement|Implement]] CDIO *[[BDolge/BycycleTurnSignal/CDIO/Minimal_Operation|Operate]] CDIO * ===Group Narrative=== ====Week 1====
For the first project for ENES 100 we were assigned with a group of [http://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:Amotaher9224 Arien Motaher], [http://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:Asadabbas Asad Gillani], [http://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:CFernandez Carlos Fernandez], [http://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:Senami Eldrick Kinmakon],and [http://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:Kszostak2139 Kevin Szostak]. Our goal was to design a bicycle turn signal. · Each year, more than 500,000 people go to the emergency room for bicycle injuries. More than 700 people die from those injuries. · Children 15 years and younger are the biggest risk. · Bicycle injuries and deaths cost $8 billion each year. After hours of brainstorming and defining the problem, we had agreed on a basic design for the bicycle turn signal. Our objective was to create a bicycle turn signal that would mounted on a back of a bicycle and it would have left and right signals to assist the rider make safe turns and warn traffic of their presence. Safety of the rider seemed like a huge priority for this project, so we tried to mold design around the safety concept. So our goal was to create a very simple but yet effective turn signal that would portable enough to have the ability to switch bicycles and deliver maximum safety. We plan to execute by having a big enough LED matrix on the back of a bicycle which could be seen at night by cars and pedestrians, the LED turn signal will controlled by 2 independent switch mounted on the front handle bars of the bicycle. So for week 1, the the team researched 4 major components of this project. We decided we need to focus on, and we came up with POSSIBLE options * Housing-Figure out ways to house the components and parts of the project. - 3D printed case - Factory manufactured housing from online - Use a med-kit type box - use everyday found boxes such as Altoids boxes to house the Arduino * Power- Figure out ways to power the the device - Use a USB - Battery - Generator by using the mechanical kinetic energy of the spinning wheels * Interface- Figure out a the main "brain" for our device, something that will control the LEDS through coding - Arduino - Simple circuits - Direct wires from LEDs to battery * Control Options - Voice control - Switches - Gyro meter, which would activate the turn signal when the bicycle leans left or right when making turns.
====Week 2====
After looking into many options for each of our issues we eliminated many pricier options to make it as cost effective as possible
These were out final decisions:
Housing - We decided that we will custom 3D printed back housing with our specifications. we measured the box would need to have the dimensions of about 3.6in x 5in x 1.8in to fit a Arduino and a battery.
Battery - We decided that a 9v alkaline battery would be efficient to power 20+ LEDs. For Interface- We decided that a Arduino would be the best because it of it huge coding availability which will allow us to have 100% control of the LEDs lighting sequence, and it would be also easier to implement a switch and a buzzer.
Control - We decided basic pushbutton would be great because it will be the most convenient and easiest to merge in with the Arduino and the LED. Simple switches eliminates the hassle of overdoing the project and it keeps true to its integrity as it maintains functionality.
====Week 3====
During this week of the project we finally had all the research we needed to draw up how we wanted our prototype to look. We looked online at what types of boxes were already made with the 3D printer that fit our dimensions so that it could be used as housing for the battery, Arduino and LEDs/bread board. We then measured how well it would fit to the bike and determined we would need about 2-3ft of wire to get from wire to get from where the housing, then the wire would follow the frame and end at the handle bars where our two push buttons and devices to hold them with would be.
All together what seemed pretty straight forward, building turn signals, turned into a great deal of work. We decided not to use Sketchup or CAD to draw up our project because each bike is different and what were making has no moving parts just light bulbs that have electricity passed through them. Next week we will try and finish our prototype by printing our housing on the 3D printer, since this week it was having problems keeping itself at the right melting temperature. If it is not working by next week we will have to come up with another option for housing the Arduino, LEDs/bread board and power source.
====Week 4====
During this week our group decided to go with a bigger platform for our LED lay out. We determined that the factory OEM cover for the brake reflector that came with the bike might be hard to see with the few amount of LEDs that can fit inside the housing and the contrasting colors (i.e. red/greed). To make it easier to see the lights we made a new housing out of the lego pieces for robots for a temporary period of time until we order or print our housing that will hold the power source, LEDs and arduino.
<gallery> File:Soldering wires to LEDs.JPG|soldering LED prongs to wires. File:Heatgun and shrinkwrap.JPG|sliding shrink wrap over wiring then using a heat gun to seal it. File:Breakdown prototype 2.JPG|breakdown of prototype 2 File:Prototype 2 turn signal.JPG|prototype 2 File:Prototype 2 (side).JPG|side view of prototype 2 <gallery/>
Throughout the week we worked on soldering the necessary wires to the LEDs, shrink wrapped the exposed ends and placed the LEDs into the lego covers. Once everything looked nice and clean we needed to make sure it would work and from learning house to make a light blink during the first week of class we thought it would be easy and were so very wrong, so while we finish up the housing we will need to find or code a program for the arduino(s) that will make the LEDs blink for a set period of time from two switches that can be mounted on the handle bars of the bike. We are trying to keep everything easily removable because we want this in the end to be able to fit onto any bike.
Our main goals we are trying to accomplish are to have a bike turn signal that blinks for a set period of time and then goes off in you forget or are not sure we wanted it to turn off, we want it to be durable and easily removable so the power source, LEDs and arduino(s) are all going into one rugged container that will have wires running from the housing to the push buttons mounted on the handle bars that will control the LEDs.
However, we have now determined our original plan to use just one arduino will most likely not work because there are too many wires and not enough connectors on the arduino so we will be working on next week a way to overcome this but trying to keep it all easily removable. One idea that is at that top of our list is have two arduino's running so that there will be enough spaces. Next week we will be finishing up our second prototype for the turn signal and then if that is accomplished we will determine if the wiring is possible for two arduino's because the middle two bars with LEDs that are not curved will need to light up with both switches.
<gallery>
</gallery>
====Week 5==== Code for the Arduino /* Blink Turns on an LED on for one second, then off for one second, repeatedly.
This example code is in the public domain. */ // Pin 13 has an LED connected on most Arduino boards. // give it a name: int led = 13; // the setup routine runs once when you press reset: void setup() { // initialize the digital pin as an output. pinMode(led, OUTPUT); } // the loop routine runs over and over again forever: void loop() { digitalWrite(led, HIGH); // turn the LED on (HIGH is the voltage level) delay(1000); // wait for a second digitalWrite(led, LOW); // turn the LED off by making the voltage LOW delay(1000); // wait for a second }
====Week 6====
This week we designed our housing for the LEDs, battery and arduino(s) and are drawing the program in sketchup so that hopefully we may print by next week. We are currently still waiting on the LEDs we ordered and cannot set up or next prototype without these next multicolored LEDs.
<gallery> File:Specs for housing.JPG|Prototype twos dimensions for 3D printing <gallery/>

=Problem Statement = The challenge was to design a pet feeder that would allow the owner to limit a pet's access to food and control the quantity of food dispensed at a given time (HS).
= Conceive = ===Why=== The first step in any project needs to begin with defining a solid and concise statement. As our groups were first assigned [https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:Merielle213 Heidi Schultz] had already had an idea of what she wanted to design. Even with a preliminary design [https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/User:MTomaselli I] knew that there were still a plethora of questions and concerns that needed to be addressed. The first and foremost, which I knew from previous experience, was establishing a client base. Knowing exactly what our customer market was would allow us to gear our design specifically for who we wanted to sell to. For example, I brought up the point that whatever our final product was going to be it needed to be of an appropriate size because having pets I knew that I wouldn't want another bulk item sitting in my living room. The conceive process in any project, especially a group project, is ultimately the most important task of them all. It not only drives a common agreement in moving forward but it is the decision that I refer back to every time there's a question regarding what, specifically, I need to accomplish (MT).
===Original Inspiration=== * [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YejpfCDh4Lc Timed Pet food Dispenser] * [http://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-controled-dog-foodtreat-dispenser/ Screw/rotating Feeder Inspiration] *[http://www.instructables.com/id/RFID-pet-feeder/ RFID-triggered feeder] * [[File:Heidi's Obese cat.jpg|Heidi's Obese Cat]]
=Design=
===Requirements=== *relatively small *allow access to food relatively quickly when approached *hide food relatively quickly if the wrong pet approached *easy to clean *buildable using materials found in the HCC Engineering Lab *dispense food in 1/4 cup increments *act in response to a pet wearing or implanted with an RFID chip approaching the apparatus (HS).
===Design Alternatives=== *bowl rotator that would hide 3 bowls and make one accessible at all times- servos we had to work with were not powerful enough to turn a platform holding four bowls, and using a DC motor would have required adding sensors and became unnecessarily complicated. *"screw" feeder to dispense food, rather than the final rotating food dispenser. The screw feeder would have been more complicated to measure the quantity of food, though it may have used less torque to control.
'''Other alternatives considered included:''' * Automatically dispensed vs. owner-measured food * Magnet vs. RFID control * Food inside a transparent box with RFID triggered door-lock vs. food bowl inside containment. * 3D-printed housing vs. handmade * Battery vs. corded power supply (HS).
===Initial Design=== *cylindrical or rectangular housing to hold pet food *"screw/twisting" style dispenser below it. *Food from dispenser fed through a tube to a bowl on a rotating platform * When a pet approached, an arduino received the signal from an RFID reader and instructed the appropriate bowl to rotate out of a covered compartment and into the open for access, then food would be dispensed into the bowl. *Then, the arduino instructed the food dipenser to release the appropriate number of 1/4 cup food increments into the bowl. *The RFID reader would read microchips that were either implanted under the pet's skin or worn on a collar.
===Prototypes Needed=== Prototype out of available materials scaled for a small dog or cat Includes: *Arduino for control *9 volt battery for power *servos for movement *Hosing from wood or plastic
The next step would be to create an improved prototype out of superior materials , taking into consideration any feedback or discoveries from Prototype 1 and making appropriate changes. Once this prototype has been perfected we create scaled up versions in sizes appropriate for larger pets. The larger versions may need increased torque from a servo and possibly increased power to support the torque-providing device (HS).
===Modeling and simulation=== Each piece of the physical unit was designed in [http://www.sketchup.com/?gclid=CLiC97vUvb0CFWuhOgodq1YAAg Sketchup2014] prior to prototyping. This allowed for detailed evaluation of specifications and potential issues prior to creation. I believe this led to a smoother constructions process (HS). The file can be reached [https://www.dropbox.com/sh/i5hj517087f35wr/uDpY-em4Nb here]
<gallery>
File:Pet Food Dispenser.png|Pet Food Storage and Dispenser File:Bowl housing without components - to illustrate lid and groove design.png|Bowl housing without components - to illustrate lid/ groove design File:Feeder box with gear components.png|Feeder box with gear components </gallery> (HS)
===Aesthetics and human factors===
We attempted to keep the entire apparatus as small in overall size as possible. It takes up a floor space of 12"x6" and a wall space of approximately 6" x 18-24".
The prototype is not nearly as attractive as the final product ought to be. Ideally we would use a smooth, attractive plastic for most of the pieces to improve aesthetic value and make cleaning the unit easy. The final product will also not allow easy access to the moving, electrical, and mechanical components - lids and covers will be secured with screws.
==Final Design==
*3x6x12 inch box with a groove 1/8 inch from the top edge for the lid to slide in * right side is slightly larger to allow for a piece of rack gear to protrude into the compartment and link with the gear assembly and still be able to retract completely to open * mounts for the servo (see the below image) * converted the measurements to inches and used those illustrated in the image below. <gallery> File:Futabaspecs.png|Getting servo specs and converting to inches File:Feeder box.png|Feeder box with gear assembly </gallery>
* box lid slides 5.75 inches but the box was only 3 inches high and the servo that turns the gears can only turn 180 degrees. So, any gear that fits inside the box would not have a large enough diameter to have a circumference (that moves the lid) large enough. *Gears 0.9 and 2.25 inches in diameter create the proper turning distance of 5.75 inches when the servo turns them '''105.4 degrees'''.
*Gear Creation: #Sketchup plugin that allows for relatively easy gear creation can be downloaded at ||http://www.ohyeahcad.com/download/%7C%7C. # this plugin only works in Sketchup 8 or earlier versions, downloadable at ||http://google-sketchup-pro.en.softonic.com%7C%7C. # After downloading both of these files the plugin .rbz file must be manually placed into the Google > Sketchup8 > plugins folder. The gear function is found under menu item Draw > Involute Gear. #I left the pressure angle at 20 degrees (If the gear teeth are not perfectly square, that is, they are slightly rounded or cut off at an angle, the pressure angle is the angle between the vertical side of the tooth and the line that angles away from it to the horizontal side of the tooth). #The teeth and pitch radius determine whether the teeth of two gears fit together. Pitch radius 0.45 and 1.125 inches. 12 and 30 gear teeth respectively. # teeth:gear ratio must be the same for each gear (See images below). <gallery> File:Rack for feeder box.png|Rack gear on underside of feeder box lid File:FeederBoxGears.png|Gears to open feeder box lid </gallery> (HS)
=Implement= Currently working on the Implement phase of the project, we still have to map out all of the potential dilemmas we face with the project. <u>'''All files and code prepared for this project can be found [https://www.dropbox.com/sh/i5hj517087f35wr/uDpY-em4Nb here].'''</u>
=Operate=
*[[BDolge/AutomaticPetFeeder/CDIO/Minimal_Conceive|Conceive]] CDIO *[[BDolge/AutomaticPetFeeder/CDIO/Minimal_Design|Design]] CDIO *[[BDolge/AutomaticPetFeeder/CDIO/Minimal_Implement|Implement]] CDIO *[[BDolge/AutomaticPetFeeder/CDIO/Minimal_Operation|Operate]] CDIO *

{{ambox|type=content|text='''Was this page [[Wikibooks:Deletion policy#Speedy deletions|created by accident or as a test?]]''' Please clarify what the intentions of this page are on the [[{{TALKPAGENAME}}|discussion page]]. The page might be able to remain at [[WB:WIW|Wikibooks]] after 7 days when further development is likely.
''Please consider notifying the author(s) with {{tlxs|Query notice|{{FULLPAGENAME}}|~~~~}} {{ #if: This page should be part of a book but there is no book called BDolge. If it should be part of a user's user space then it should be mentioned that Wikibooks is not a hosting service. Generally books should be developed in the main space where they are accessible and editable by anybody. | *''Additional comments: This page should be part of a book but there is no book called BDolge. If it should be part of a user's user space then it should be mentioned that Wikibooks is not a hosting service. Generally books should be developed in the main space where they are accessible and editable by anybody.'' }} }}{{#ifeq:no|yes|| [[Category:{{#ifexpr:{{lastedit}} >= 7|Candidates for speedy deletion|Queried pages}}|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]}} ==Problem Statement== The challenge was to design a pet feeder that would allow the owner to limit a pet's access to food and control the quantity of food dispensed at a given time. ==The Design Process== =====Requirements for each element or component derived from system level goals and requirements===== The pet food bowl housing needed to be relatively small, allow access to food relatively quickly when approached, and hide food relatively quickly if the wrong pet approached. It also needed to be easy to clean and buildable using materials found in the HCC Engineering Lab. The food "hopper" which holds the bulk food and dispenses it at the appropriate time also needed to take up as little space as possible, in conjunction with the bowl housing. It was decided that it should dispense food in 1/4 cup increments. It also had to be built out of materials in the Engineering lab. Both of these would be required to act in response to a pet wearing or implanted with an RFID chip approaching the apparatus. =====Alternatives in design===== The group initially considered using a bowl rotator that would hide 3 bowls and make one accessible at all times. This idea was set aside when it became clear that the servos we had to work with were not powerful enough to turn a platform holding four bowls, and using a DC motor would have required adding sensors and became unnecessarily complicated. It also used a "screw" feeder to dispense food, rather than the final rotating food dispenser. The screw feeder would have been more complicated to measure the quantity of food, though it may have used less torque to control. =====The initial design===== The initial design consisted of a cylindrical or rectangular housing to hold pet food, with a rotating dispenser below it. Food from that dispenser was fed through a tube to the bowl housing. The bowl sat in the forward compartment and the components that operate it in the rear compartment. When a pet approached, an arduino received the signal from an RFID reader and instructed the bowl housing to retract its lid. Then, the arduino instructed the food dipenser to release the appropriate number of 1/4 cup food increments into the bowl. File:Pet Food Dispenser.png|Pet Food Storage and Dispenser File:Bowl housing without components - to illustrate lid and groove design.png|Bowl housing without components - to illustrate lid/ groove design File:Feeder box with gear components.png|Feeder box with gear components The sketchup file containing these designs can be found [https://www.dropbox.com/sh/i5hj517087f35wr/uDpY-em4Nb here]. =====Experiment prototypes and tests need for design===== ==Modeling, simulation and test== ==Multi-Objective Design (DFX)== =====Performance, life cycle cost and value===== =====Aesthetics and human factors===== =====Implementation, verification, test and environmental sustainability===== =====Operations===== =====Maintainability, reliability, and safety===== =====Robustness, evolution, product improvement and retirement===== ==Poster== ==Next Steps==

CONCEIVING AND ENGINEERING SYSTEMS
==Idea==
Make a bicycle turn signal out of LEDs that can be mounted on almost any bike and that gives the user control of the turn signal without losing the ability to also use there arm as a turn signal.
==Problem Statement== · Each year, more than 500,000 people go to the emergency room for bicycle injuries in the USA. More than 700 people die from those injuries.
· Children 15 years and younger are the biggest risk.
· Bicycle injuries and deaths cost $8 billion each year.
·Adolescents/Young people(ages 15-24) and adults aged 45 and older have the highest death rates.
·Males are more likely to get injured than females.
·Most of all bicycle deaths happen in urban areas and non-intersection areas.
==Setting System Goals and Requirements== ===Market/Customer needs===
* Competitive Bike Riders * Leisurely Bike Riders * Supply a proactive safety mechanism to a market that lends to $8 billion in annual cost resulting from injury and death. By implementing an easily recognizable safety system, it is not only the biker community that benefits, but automobile operators, and local government- with benefits trickling down to taxpayers as well.
===Factors that set the context of the requirements===
* Customer Needs (MT) * Cost of Materials (MT) * Time/Duration of Project (MT) * Aesthetics (MT) * Practicality (MT) * Marketability (MT) * Available Resources (MT)
=====Enterprise goals and capabilities=====
* Simplicity * Cost effectiveness * Employ a product that can easily be integrated in any enterprise scenario that would call for such an item.
=====Competitors and benchmarking information=====
=====Ethical, social, environmental, legal and regulatory influences=====
===System goals and requirements=== =====Initial target goals (based on needs, opportunities and other influences)===== =====System performance metrics=====
==Defining Function, Concept and Architecture== ===Necessary system functions===
* Provide luminance that projects a minimum of 10ft * components mounted upon a surface area visible from a minimum of 10ft away * LED placement distinguishable as arrows * Ability to indicate movement of two directions (left and right)
===System concepts===
===Trade-offs among concepts===
===High level architectural form and structure=== ===The decomposition of form into subsystems, assignment of functions to subsystems, and definition of interfaces===
==Modeling of System and Ensuring Goals Can Be Met== ===Appropriate models of technical performance=== ===The plan of implementation and operations=== ===Trade-offs among various goals and functions===
==Development Project Management== ===Project cost and schedule===
* Additional Costs (not originally provided by class) * $7.50 - set of LED Holders * $7.95 - 25 Pack of LED * TBD - Cost of 3D printed housing
===Estimation and allocation of resources=== ===Risks and alternatives=== *Users could depend on using general hand signals *Risk of limited sight range
==Poster== ==Next Steps==

revision.comment: Added links, OMML remark, and a little formatting.
revision.text:
This book is about the ''Math Builder'' tool in Microsoft Word versions 2007 and higher. It also applies to Microsoft PowerPoint 2010 and higher. Note that this is a different tool than the legacy tool ''Equation editior 3.0'' and ''Mathtype''.
Typesetting mathematics on a computer has always been a challenge. The mathematical community almost universally accepts a typesetting language called LaTeX. ''Math Builder'' is a much easier to use tool that has less more functionality than [[Wikipedia: LaTeX|LaTeX]] but more than typical document processing. Microsoft call this hybrid language the ''Office Math Markup Language'', or OMML for short. It is an appropriate tool for: *Typing any document whose focus is not itself mathematics. *Typing a short mathematics document quickly. *A stepping stone between word processing (MS Word) and typesetting (LaTeX) Note that Math Builder does not perform any mathematics: it is a took for displaying it.
== Pros and Cons == '''Pros:''' *Math Builder is [[Wikipedia: WYSIWYG|WYSIWYG]]: after typing an equation you see immediately what it looks like. *It's easy to get started: it's already built in to Microsoft Word. Common symbols have point-and-click icons. *It's easy to use: Common symbols have keyboard shortcuts so that a veteran user need not use a mouse at all. *Nearly all symbols use the same commands as LaTeX. *The format used is non-proprietary and given in Unicode Technical Note #28.
'''Cons:''' *Some uncommon symbols are not listed in the menu and require knowing the keyboard shortcut. Typically this is the LaTeX code for the symbol. *There are differences between Math Builder and LaTeX code: advanced functionality that requires more than just a symbol tend to follow the same flavor but have slightly different syntax. Math Builder code tends to be shorter than LaTeX code and disappears upon completion to the WYSIWYG output. Examples here are matrices, multiple aligned equations, and binomial coefficients. *No LaTeX typesetting tools such as labels and references are implemented. *No highly advanced LaTeX tools such as graphing, commutative diagrams, or geometric shapes are implemented. *Students studying mathematics might not be motivated to learn LaTeX because they might be able to get by with ''Equation Builder'' in Word to satisfy the vast majority of their needs. However, when such a student reaches the limits, unlike LaTeX there is absolutely no recourse to expand the program to satisfy it.
== Inserting an equation == Microsoft Word has two different typing environments: text and math. To obtain the math environment, click on "Equation" on the "Insert" ribbon. The keyboard shortcut is "alt"+ "=". Everything you type in this environment is considered math: all automatic formatting of text is disabled. To exit the math environment, click on any text outside the math environment. One easy way to do this is by pressing the right arrow key.
== Common Mathematics == === Fractions === There are multiple ways to display a fraction. The default is vertically aligned as illustrated below. Obtain this by typing the fraction and pressing space: '''1/2'''
<MATH>\frac{1}{2}</MATH>
=== Parenthesis, brackets, and braces === Grouping symbols will automatically size to the appropriate size. These symbols include "(), {}, [], ||". For instance, the expression below can be obtained with '''(1/2(x+1))''':
<MATH>\left (\frac{1}{2}(x+1)\right )</MATH>
(Be careful to press space after the "2" to render the fraction, otherwise Word might put "x+1" in the denominator.) === Exponents and subscripts === Exponents can be obtained by using "^" and subscripts by "_". The monomial below can be obtained by typing '''x_2^5''' or '''x^5_2''' and pressing space.
<MATH>x_2^5</MATH>
=== Symbols: <MATH>\neq, \leq, \subseteq, \vee, \rightarrow, \Rightarrow </MATH> etc === These are all common symbols. The easiest thing to do would be to find a LaTeX reference sheet. A few of those symbols are shown here: {| class = "wikitable" |code |output |- |\neq |<MATH>\neq</MATH> |- |\leq or <= |<MATH>\leq</MATH> |- |\subseteq |<MATH>\subseteq</MATH> |- |\vee |<MATH>\vee</MATH> |- |\rightarrow |<MATH>\rightarrow</MATH> |- |\Rightarrow |<MATH>\Rightarrow</MATH> |}
=== Greek, Script, and Fraktur letters === The math environment implements 3 fronts in addition to the default. *Greek letters can be obtained by typing a "\" followed by the name of symbol. Capitalizing it creates a capital letter. '''\delta \Delta''' produces <MATH>\delta \Delta</MATH> *Script letters can be obtained by typing "\" followed by "script" followed by the letter. '''\scriptd \scriptD''' produces <MATH>\mathcal{d} \mathcal{D}</MATH> *Fraktur letters can be obtained by typing "\" followed by "fraktur" followed by the letter. Fraktur does not have capitals. '''\frakd''' prodouces <MATH>\mathfrak{d}</MATH>
=== Blackboard Bold letters === Blackboard bold letters can be obtained by typing "\" followed by "double" followed by the letter. '''\doubled \doubleD''' produces <MATH>\mathbb{d} \mathbb{D}</MATH>
=== Matrices === Matrices are obtained with the "\matrix" symbol. Use parenthesis to start and end the matrix. Use "@" to separate rows, and "&" to separate columns. The matrix below can be created by typing '''[\matrix(1&2&3@4&5&6)]'''.
<MATH>\begin{bmatrix} 1&2&3\\4&5&6\end{bmatrix}</MATH>
=== Multiple Aligned Equations === Aligning equations can be obtained with the "eqarray" symbol. Use parenthesis to stat and end the matrix. Use "@" to separate equations. Use "&" to specify alignment and whitespace. The first "&" and then every other occurrence is alignment. The second and then every other occurrence is white space. The equations below can be obtained by typing the following text: <source lang="latex">\eqarray(2&x+&3&y=5@&x+&&y=7)</source>
<MATH>\begin{align}2&x+&3&y=5\\&x+&&y=7\end{align}</MATH>
(The math environment here seems to be adding excess space between the alignments that doesn't occur in Word)
== Inline versus Display == Equations have two forms. '''Inline''' specifies that the equation is to be in line with text. This affects a few expressions to make them appear smaller. For instance fractions will use a smaller font. Summations and integrals will place the endpoints to the right of the symbol instead of below it. '''Display''' specifies to use as much space as needed. Display mode equations must appear on their own line.
== Modifying and creating shortcuts == Everything in Math Builder requires special symbols that the computer knows how to interpret. These symbols are constructed with all the commands starting with "\" as illustrated in the above sections. This is implemented via ''math autocorrect'' which you can modify. For instance, you might like to use \ra instead of \rightarrow. You can do this by adding the command to the ''math autocorrect'' directory.

revision.text:
== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Herman darman!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 22:12, 24 March 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Dotting the t's and crossing the i's */
revision.text:
Also, congrats everybody on a great, collaborative product! I'm proud of what we've accomplished in two weeks! [[User:RedheadRachel|RedheadRachel]] ([[User talk:RedheadRachel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RedheadRachel|contribs]]) 16:13, 4 April 2014 (UTC)
==Dotting the t's and crossing the i's== Hey, now more than ever I just wanted to suggest cleaning up what we've already got. We have a ton of great info already, and I feel we've more than covered the appropriate areas, and rather than just throwing in more bits and bobs I'd say perfecting what we do should be a priority. Generally just bringing formatting and such in line throughout the page, correcting any spelling or grammar errors, really just polishing what we've got till it's good an' shiny and professional! Hope that's not a problem George? ;D [[User:Flailkerrin|Flailkerrin]] ([[User talk:Flailkerrin|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Flailkerrin|contribs]]) 15:56, 4 April 2014 (UTC)
Yeah I think its a good idea just to clean things up a bit because we have loads of information and I think we have covered pretty much everything. Adding some pictures is a good touch and maybe linking things to other pages ect. And also making sure all the grammar and spelling is correct. Do we have until the end of the day to do all of this yeah? [[User:Heyrach|Heyrach]] ([[User talk:Heyrach|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Heyrach|contribs]]) 16:10, 4 April 2014 (UTC)
I don't know, timewise. I just know that Kelly.marvel and I have been doing some serious polishing/editing for consistency (like the 'always-on' stuff) as well as for content. If you others are confident in your formatting skills (I'm not so confident in mine), have at it! [[User:RedheadRachel|RedheadRachel]] ([[User talk:RedheadRachel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RedheadRachel|contribs]]) 16:13, 4 April 2014 (UTC)
Hello there guys! Has anyone else been having some serious trouble with editing conflicts preventing them posting things to the Wikibook? The past few times I've tried to add or edit it just won't let me and my text just disappears. I don't know it's just me are not... From now on I'm writing stuff on word like Greg suggested before,but it's been infuriating! How have other people been finding it? [[User:LittleBlondeLottie|LittleBlondeLottie]] ([[User talk:LittleBlondeLottie|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/LittleBlondeLottie|contribs]])
Hi Lottie, don't know if this will be too late but when an editing conflict occurs you just need to click back the page to get your work back. Then just copy and paste it into the new version. [[User:GemmaMiller|GemmaMiller]] ([[User talk:GemmaMiller|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/GemmaMiller|contribs]]) 16:36, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
Hey guys. I was wondering if we should include sub headings within the Main concepts section for each concept ? Was thinking it would be a good way to organize the different concepts? What do you guys think ? ([[User:Kaf00023|Kaf00023]] ([[User talk:Kaf00023|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Kaf00023|contribs]]) 22:34, 24 March 2014 (UTC))
Hey. I agree, I think having subheadings will make the page look more organised and professional. I think that we should start with a detailed description of the actual idea of Always-On Culture and then move on to Turkle and Boyd's ideas, each under their own subheading. What does everyone think? Also, is there something obvious I have missed? [[User:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|KathrynHairUpAndGlasses]] ([[User talk:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|contribs]]) 15:34, 26 March 2014 (UTC)
Should we change the main concepts to be more a section for each thinker than each concepts, or just add each of the main thinkers at the end or start of the section ? ([[User:Kaf00023|Kaf00023]] ([[User talk:Kaf00023|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Kaf00023|contribs]]) 22:41, 27 March 2014 (UTC))
Hi guys. I wanted to put in something about the fact that teenagers are more associated with "always-on culture" than any other group of people. Any suggestions of where, under which sub-heading, I should put it? Thanks! [[User:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|KathrynHairUpAndGlasses]] ([[User talk:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|contribs]]) 13:50, 28 March 2014 (UTC)
''''reduced context cues'''' why the double bold here and not elsewhere? Try to be consistent with formatting :o) [[User:GregXenon01|GregXenon01]] ([[User talk:GregXenon01|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/GregXenon01|contribs]]) 15:07, 28 March 2014 (UTC)
Sorry about the double bold on social context cues it was a mistake on my part when making the sub heading and i didn't notice the error till today, however I've fixed it now and will check more carefully next time. As for teenagers being more associated with 'always on culture' you could work it into the idea of being part of a network as they would presumably be the largest part of said network and the implications of that ? ([[User:Kaf00023|Kaf00023]] ([[User talk:Kaf00023|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Kaf00023|contribs]]) 22:58, 28 March 2014 (UTC))
We should be sure to remain consistent with danah boyd's name. Some people are capitalising it when she is known for having it in lower case (even her Wikipedia page has it in lower case). (If anyone is dead against lower case just say here so everyone knows to put it like that). Thanks! [[User:SiobhanDMC|SiobhanDMC]] ([[User talk:SiobhanDMC|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/SiobhanDMC|contribs]]) 16:53, 31 March 2014 (UTC)
Should we capitalize boyd's name when it is in the beginning of the sentence? --[[User:Kelly.marvel|Kelly.marvel]] ([[User talk:Kelly.marvel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Kelly.marvel|contribs]]) 17:55, 31 March 2014 (UTC)
Good idea about putting the idea about teenagers being more associated with always on in the networking section. Thanks. I think if her name is lower case even on her Wikipedia page that we should keep it lower case throughout. [[User:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|KathrynHairUpAndGlasses]] ([[User talk:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|contribs]]) 18:14, 31 March 2014 (UTC)
I've noticed that there are several different ways that we are saying "Always-On Culture". Some have upper and lower case, some all upper case, some all lower case and some are in and some are out of quotations. I think they should all be the same, with perhaps the exception of the first time it should be in upper case. Do you think it should have "" quotations or ''? [[User:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|KathrynHairUpAndGlasses]] ([[User talk:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|contribs]]) 18:33, 31 March 2014 (UTC)
I agree Kathryn that we need to be a bit more consistent in the formatting of the words "Always On Culture". In the module handbook and all our other course material the topic is refered to as 'Always On' Culture - with the culture aspect being titled as 'Always On' not an entire clause phrase and capitalising the C in 'Culture'. I hope that's helpful, what do others think? [[User:LittleBlondeLottie|LittleBlondeLottie]] ([[User talk:LittleBlondeLottie|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/LittleBlondeLottie|contribs]])
I think we should go with what the handbook says. Also, are we putting the references in alphabetical order? Do you think it would look better or do you think they should be in line with where they are in the text? As in, if the reference comes first in the text should it come first in the reference list? [[User:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|KathrynHairUpAndGlasses]] ([[User talk:KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/KathrynHairUpAndGlasses|contribs]]) 19:02, 31 March 2014 (UTC)
I'm not sure about the references - alphabetical will probably look better but the majority of Wiki pages/books have them in the order they are references in [[User:SiobhanDMC|SiobhanDMC]] ([[User talk:SiobhanDMC|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/SiobhanDMC|contribs]]) 19:17, 31 March 2014 (UTC)
I think we need to link our references to where they are located in the text. Also, the citations in the text are not all formatted in the same way. --[[User:Kelly.marvel|Kelly.marvel]] ([[User talk:Kelly.marvel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Kelly.marvel|contribs]]) 14:29, 1 April 2014 (UTC)
Hey guys I had a thought about smart mobs after today's lecture. More the fact that in order to fully function, and effectively act out 'spontaneous' action, the mob has to be always on i.e. in order to quickly muster for a project with a deadline (us) or for like a protest (like what happened in Eygpt). Anyone think its relevant enough to add in? Just to reference another chapter? [[User:RobboAdare13|RobboAdare13]] ([[User talk:RobboAdare13|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RobboAdare13|contribs]]) 15:26, 1 April 2014 (UTC)
Oh yeh, just clocked the online identity page... They have a hell of a lot more content than us haha. We might have to do more reading, <u>if</u> there is anymore stuff to read about this! [[User:RobboAdare13|RobboAdare13]] ([[User talk:RobboAdare13|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RobboAdare13|contribs]]) 16:02, 1 April 2014 (UTC)
In Turkle's work on the 'tethered self' she tied in a lot of other topics such as "connections that matter" and "new forms of validation." I think it would be useful to add in subheadings under the 'tethered self' discussing these topics as well. Some content that we can include is a portion about the positive and negative aspects of being 'always on.' --[[User:Kelly.marvel|Kelly.marvel]] ([[User talk:Kelly.marvel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Kelly.marvel|contribs]]) 16:17, 1 April 2014 (UTC)
If we do add a section related to the up and downsides to always being connected, one of the downsides could be the concept of "Disconnectivity Anxiety" --[[User:Kelly.marvel|Kelly.marvel]] ([[User talk:Kelly.marvel|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Kelly.marvel|contribs]]) 16:42, 1 April 2014 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, MartinPoulter!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 22:35, 24 March 2014 (UTC)

{{Trainz-admin}} {{Text-box|This is a resource page, and certainly '''''not''' part of the book meant for direct viewing'' by readers.}} ;usage Use this page as if a template, but put the call into main space mode by inserting a leading colon just like this: 
 {{:Trainz/Trainz Highest Ver}}
Otherwise, without the lead colon, the call will be processed to template namespace. Just use in-line in a sentence following the V- or V like this: * The version number (or Trainz-build value), range from V-1.0 to V-3.7, and corresponds to requirements Trainz places on 3D asset data definitions—and ''when found in an asset {{TR|R|Config.txt file|p=configuration file}}, tells the software suite the way they are to be processed. The older the version, the more translation steps to display the 3D models in the current latest versions. It's a clever system that has allowed Trainz route builders access to literally hundreds of thousands of assets to
*where the sentence part is formed literally as shown here: range from V-1.0 to V-{{:Trainz Highest Ver}}, and corresponds to [[Category:Trainz|$Highest]][[Category:Trainz Templates|$Highest]]

page.title: Professionalism/Julia Bluhm, SPARK, and Seventeen Magazine

revision.text:
==Introduction== The use of photo manipulation software is not new, but it is recently generating a great deal of controversy. While the public generally accepts that Photoshop will be used for retouching purposes (lighting, flyaway hair, skin imperfections, and such), videos going viral demonstrate the astonishing transformation a model’s pictures undergo between a photo shoot and publication. This transformation is rooted in altering models’ bodies, often to the point where the original model is almost unrecognizable in picture. Cindy Crawford was once quoted saying, “I wish that I looked like Cindy Crawford.” The alterations to body image set unrealistic expectations about how a person should look. Is the use of photo editing software highlighting the best the model could look, or is it simply displaying an altered reality? ==In The News== Target recently received significant backlash for mistakenly published pictures on their website. These pictures advertised bathing suits in their Juniors department, but had blatant Photoshop errors, including jagged edges under the girl’s arm, a chunk missing at the apex of the girl’s thighs, and impossibly lengthened arms. The error was called out online, and went viral. Much of the outrage around this controversy stems from the fact that these products are marketed to juniors, who look to the media to set expectations about the way they should look. If the digital artist had used the correct tools and taken more time to edit precisely, or if the image was corrected before being published, many would have never guessed the images were Photoshopped. The response was as harsh as it was towards Target because the errors made it obvious that the intention of the Photoshopping of the picture was to alter the shape of the model’s body. The idea of altering body image is offensive to many, primarily because of the links between self-consciousness resulting from media images and psychological disorders such as depression. ==False Advertising== Beyond the psychological implications of photo manipulation in magazines, there are problems with maintaining integrity in advertisements. Despite general awareness that photos in magazines are Photoshopped, most often a reader of a magazine does not consciously register that the images displayed have been drastically altered, which can affect their perception of the images seen. One industry in which honesty is especially difficult to regulate is the beauty industry. The goal of an advertisement is primarily to entice the audience to purchase a product, but to what extent is it ethical to represent a beauty product with a manipulated image? In some cases, companies have crossed this line. For example, a L’Oreal advertisement depicting Julia Roberts was banned in the United Kingdom because the makeup was advertised to removed wrinkles and crow’s feet, but the company used photo manipulation to remove these features from the picture. This type of false advertising can mislead consumers. Deception in advertising can drive uninformed purchases. If Kelly Clarkson appears on the cover of a magazine promoting a diet and exercise regimen she claims worked for her, the readers would expect that her picture conveys the results of this regimen. If the readers knew her figure had been altered in the picture, they could adjust their expectations, putting less faith in a regimen which has not demonstrated its results fairly to the readers.
==Julia Bluhm & SPARK== ===Petition against Photoshop=== ===Seventeen Magazine=== ==Other Advertising Examples== ===Companies Leading the Charge Against Photoshop===
==Conclusion==
